material.mattext: What does the design matrix \(X\) in multiple linear regression include for the model \(Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_{i1} + \beta_2 X_{i2} + \varepsilon_i\)?
Only the predictor variables X1 and X2
The predictor variables with the response Y as the first column
A column of ones followed by columns for X1 and X2
The predictor variables X1 and X2 centered at their means
In the regression model \(Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2 + \varepsilon\), what does \(\beta_1\) represent?
The total effect of X1 on Y across all values of X2
The effect of X1 on Y when X2 equals zero
The change in mean Y per unit increase in X1, holding X2 constant
The correlation coefficient between X1 and Y
What happens to \(R^2\) when you add another predictor variable to a regression model?
It always decreases because the model becomes more complex
It either stays the same or increases, never decreases
It increases only if the new predictor is statistically significant
It remains unchanged unless the new predictor is highly correlated with Y
Which statement about adjusted \(R^2\) is correct?
It always equals or exceeds the regular \(R^2\) value
It penalizes models with fewer predictors
It can decrease when adding non-informative predictors to the model
It is always preferred over PRESS for model selection
In matrix notation for multiple regression, what is the dimension of the matrix \(X'X\)?
\(n \times n\) where n is sample size
\((p+1) \times (p+1)\) where p is the number of predictors
\(n \times p\) where n is sample size and p is the number of predictors
\(p \times p\) where p is the number of parameters including the intercept
The OLS estimator \(\mathbf{b} = (X'X)^{-1}X'y\) assumes that:
\(X'X\) is non-singular (invertible)
The predictors are uncorrelated with each other
The sample size exceeds the number of predictors by at least 10
All predictors are measured on the same scale
What does SSR (regression sum of squares) measure?
The total variability in the response variable Y
The variability in Y explained by the regression model
The variability in Y not explained by the model
The average squared distance between observed and predicted values
In testing \(H_0: \beta_1 = \beta_2 = 0\), which test statistic is appropriate?
The t-test for individual coefficients
The global F-test for overall regression relation
The Bonferroni-adjusted t-test
The partial F-test comparing nested models
What is the correct interpretation of a 95% confidence interval for \(\beta_1\)?
There is a 95% probability that the true \(\beta_1\) falls in this interval
We are 95% confident the true \(\beta_1\) is contained in this interval
95% of the observed data points fall within this interval
The interval will capture \(\beta_1\) in 95% of samples from the population
When calculating joint confidence intervals using the Bonferroni procedure for g intervals with family confidence level \(1-\alpha\), each individual interval uses:
Confidence level \(1 - \alpha\)
Confidence level \(1 - \alpha/2\)
Confidence level \(1 - \alpha/g\)
Confidence level \(1 - \alpha/(2g)\)
What is the key difference between a confidence interval and a prediction interval?
Prediction intervals are always narrower than confidence intervals
Confidence intervals account for new observation variability
Prediction intervals include both estimation uncertainty and new observation variability
There is no practical difference for large sample sizes
The coefficient of partial determination \(R^2_{Y1|2}\) represents:
The correlation between Y and X1
The total variation in Y explained by X1
The proportion of Y variation not explained by X2 that is explained by adding X1
The proportion of X1 variation explained by X2
In the model with X1 and X2, if the coefficient \(b_1\) from the simple regression \(Y \sim X_1\) differs greatly from \(b_1\) in the multiple regression \(Y \sim X_1 + X_2\), this suggests:
The model assumptions are violated
X1 should be dropped from the model
X1 and X2 are correlated with each other
The sample size is too small for multiple regression
What does \(SSR(X_1|X_2)\) represent?
The sum of squares for regression with only X1
The sum of squares for regression with only X2
The extra sum of squares from adding X1 to a model already containing X2
The correlation between X1 and X2
If predictors X1 and X2 are orthogonal (uncorrelated), then:
\(SSR(X_1) = SSR(X_1|X_2)\) and the regression coefficients are the same in simple and multiple regression
The multiple regression model is invalid
\(R^2\) will always equal 1
You must use standardized regression coefficients
Standardized regression coefficients are obtained by:
Dividing each coefficient by its standard error
Multiplying each coefficient by the sample size
Fitting the model after centering and scaling all variables to mean 0 and variance 1
Converting all coefficients to the same units of measurement
When is it meaningful to compare standardized regression coefficients to assess relative importance?
Always, regardless of the correlation structure among predictors
Only when all predictors are measured on the same scale
When multicollinearity among predictors is low
Never, because they ignore the units of measurement
In a quadratic regression model \(Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \beta_2 X^2 + \varepsilon\), if \(\beta_2 < 0\), the fitted curve:
Has a minimum turning point
Has a maximum turning point (inverted U-shape)
Is monotonically increasing
Is linear because \(\beta_2\) adjusts for curvature
Why is it recommended to use centered predictors \((X' = X - \bar{X})\) in polynomial regression?
To ensure the model has an intercept
To make \(\beta_1\) easier to interpret
To reduce multicollinearity between X and \(X^2\) terms
To guarantee that \(R^2\) equals 1
In a centered quadratic model \(Y = \beta_0' + \beta_1' X' + \beta_2' (X')^2\), what does \(\beta_1'\) estimate?
The slope at \(X = 0\)
The slope at the mean of X \((X = \bar{X})\)
The average slope across all values of X
The curvature of the relationship
To test whether a quadratic term is necessary in the model, you would test:
The lack of fit F-test compares:
A simple linear model to a quadratic model
The fitted regression model to a model with a separate mean for each X value
Two models with different numbers of predictors
The full model to an intercept-only model
In the interaction model \(E\{Y\} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2 + \beta_3 X_1X_2\), the coefficient \(\beta_3\) represents:
The combined effect of X1 and X2
The correlation between X1 and X2
How much the effect of X1 on Y changes per unit increase in X2
The average effect of X1 across all levels of X2
If an interaction term \(X_1X_2\) is significant in the model, this means:
X1 and X2 must be highly correlated
The effect of X1 on Y depends on the level of X2
Both X1 and X2 should be removed from the model
The model violates the linearity assumption
When plotting conditional effects for an interaction model, parallel lines indicate:
No interaction effect between the predictors
A strong positive interaction effect
That one predictor should be dropped
Perfect multicollinearity between predictors
For a qualitative variable with k categories, how many indicator variables are needed?
k indicator variables
\(k - 1\) indicator variables
\(k + 1\) indicator variables
2k indicator variables
In a regression model with region as a factor (NE, NC, S, W) using W as the reference category, the coefficient for regionNE represents:
The mean response for the NE region
The difference between NE and all other regions combined
The difference in mean response between NE and W regions, holding other variables constant
The correlation between region and the response
Which R function is used to change the reference level of a factor variable?
factor()
as.factor()
relevel()
reference()
To test whether region has any effect in a model with other predictors, you would:
Test each region coefficient individually using t-tests
Use a partial F-test comparing models with and without the region variable
Check if the confidence intervals for region coefficients contain zero
Calculate the VIF for the region variable
When using Bonferroni simultaneous confidence intervals for g comparisons, why does the individual confidence level increase to \(1 - \alpha/g\)?
To make the intervals narrower
To maintain the desired family-wise confidence level across all g intervals
Because each comparison uses a different sample
To account for multiple testing bias
In model selection, what does Mallows' \(C_p\) statistic measure?
The correlation between predicted and observed values
The total mean squared error of prediction including bias and variance
The percentage of variation explained by the model
The likelihood of the model being the true model
A model with \(C_p\) approximately equal to p (number of parameters) suggests:
The model has small bias and is a good candidate
The model is overfitting the data
The model should include more predictors
Severe multicollinearity is present
What is the PRESS statistic?
The sum of squared errors from the fitted model
The residual standard error adjusted for sample size
The sum of squared prediction errors using leave-one-out cross-validation
The F-statistic for testing overall model significance
If PRESS is much larger than SSE, this suggests:
The model fits the data very well
All predictors are significant
The model may not predict new observations well (overfitting)
The assumptions of normality are violated
Which model selection criterion penalizes model complexity most heavily?
Adjusted \(R^2\)
AIC (Akaike Information Criterion)
BIC (Bayesian Information Criterion, also called SBC)
Mallows' \(C_p\)
In "best subset" regression, you:
Test all possible models and select the one with highest \(R^2\)
Add predictors one at a time using forward selection
Fit all possible models and compare them using selection criteria like \(C_p\), AIC, or adjusted \(R^2\)
Remove predictors one at a time using backward elimination
The variance inflation factor (VIF) for predictor \(X_j\) measures:
The variance of the errors in the regression model
The correlation between \(X_j\) and the response Y
How much the variance of the coefficient estimate for \(X_j\) is inflated due to multicollinearity
The influence of outliers on the coefficient for \(X_j\)
A VIF value greater than 10 typically indicates:
The predictor is not significant
The model assumptions are violated
Serious multicollinearity exists for that predictor
The predictor should definitely be removed from the model
In residual analysis, a plot of residuals versus fitted values showing a funnel shape suggests:
The linearity assumption is violated
The constant variance (homoscedasticity) assumption is violated
The errors are not normally distributed
Influential observations are present
An added-variable plot (partial regression plot) for predictor \(X_k\) shows:
The residuals from the full model plotted against \(X_k\)
The marginal relationship between Y and \(X_k\) after removing the linear effects of other predictors
The leverage of observations based on \(X_k\)
The interaction between \(X_k\) and all other predictors
Studentized deleted residuals are used to:
Test the normality assumption
Identify outlying Y observations with more stable variance estimates
Measure the leverage of observations
Detect multicollinearity among predictors
The diagonal elements of the hat matrix \((h_{ii})\) measure:
The magnitude of the residuals
The influence of observations on coefficient estimates
The leverage or outlyingness of observations in the X-space
The correlation between predictors
An observation with \(h_{ii} > 2p/n\) is considered:
An outlier in Y
An influential observation
An outlying observation with respect to its X values (high leverage)
A violation of the normality assumption
Cook's distance for an observation measures:
How far the observation is from the mean of Y
The leverage of the observation
The overall influence of the observation on all fitted values
Whether the observation violates normality
DFFITS for observation i measures:
The change in all coefficients when observation i is deleted
The change in \(R^2\) when observation i is deleted
The change in the fitted value \(\hat{Y}_i\) when observation i is deleted
The studentized residual for observation i
DFBETAS measures:
The change in \(R^2\) when a predictor is removed
The standardized change in SSE
The standardized change in each regression coefficient when an observation is deleted
The correlation between residuals and fitted values
The Bonferroni outlier test procedure for identifying outlying Y observations:
Tests each observation separately at level \(\alpha\)
Tests the maximum studentized deleted residual at level \(\alpha/n\) to maintain family error rate
Removes all observations with \(|t_i| > 2\)
Uses the hat matrix to identify leverage points
To test the normality assumption, you calculate the correlation between ordered residuals and their expected values under normality. If this correlation is very close to 1:
The normality assumption appears reasonable
The normality assumption is violated
The model has perfect fit
Multicollinearity is present
If you fit a model and find VIF values all close to 1, this indicates:
The model is overfitting
All predictors are highly significant
There is little to no multicollinearity among the predictors
The response and predictors are uncorrelated
A residual plot against a predictor \(X_k\) not in the model that shows a pattern suggests:
The current model is adequate
\(X_k\) is highly correlated with predictors already in the model
\(X_k\) might be a useful addition to the model
Multicollinearity is a serious problem
When you fit \(Y \sim X_1\) and get \(R^2 = 0.75\), then fit \(Y \sim X_1 + X_2\) and get \(R^2 = 0.76\), this suggests:
X2 is highly significant and should definitely be included
X2 explains very little additional variation beyond what X1 already explains
X1 should be removed from the model
The model with both predictors violates assumptions
For a model \(Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2 + \varepsilon\), if you want to test whether both predictors can be simultaneously dropped, you would test:
\(H_0: \beta_1 = \beta_2 = 0\) using a global F-test
\(H_0: \beta_1 = 0\) and separately \(H_0: \beta_2 = 0\)
In R, to fit a polynomial regression \(Y \sim X + X^2\), you should use:
lm(Y ~ X + X^2, data = df)
lm(Y ~ X + I(X^2), data = df)
lm(Y ~ poly(X, 2), data = df)
Both b and c are correct
To create an interaction term between X1 and X2 in R's lm() function, you can use:
lm(Y ~ X1 + X2 + X1*X2)
lm(Y ~ X1*X2)
Both a and b are correct
lm(Y ~ X1 + X2 + I(X1*X2))
When centering a predictor in polynomial regression using \(X' = X - \bar{X}\), the relationship between the original coefficient \(\beta_2\) for \(X^2\) and the centered coefficient \(\beta_2'\) is:
\(\beta_2 = \beta_2'\) (the quadratic coefficient remains unchanged)
\(\beta_2 = \beta_2' + 2\beta_1'\bar{X}\)
\(\beta_2 = \beta_2' - \beta_1'/\bar{X}\)
Based on a residual plot showing a systematic curved pattern, you should:
Conclude the model is adequate
Remove outliers from the dataset
Consider adding polynomial or interaction terms to the model
Transform the response variable to logarithmic scale
In a dataset with \(n = 25\) observations and \(p = 4\) predictors (plus intercept), if PRESS = 450 and SSE = 400, you should:
Be confident the model predicts well
Be concerned that the model may overfit and not predict new data well
Remove all predictors from the model
Conclude that multicollinearity is severe
After fitting a model, you find Case 12 has \(h_{12} = 0.45\) (with \(2p/n = 0.24\)) and studentized deleted residual \(t_{12} = 0.8\). This observation is:
Both high leverage and an outlier in Y
High leverage but not an outlier in Y
An outlier in Y but not high leverage
Neither high leverage nor an outlier
A partial F-test is used to compare:
Two completely different datasets
Two models with the same number of predictors
A full model against a reduced model (nested models) to test whether additional parameters improve fit
The observed data to the fitted values
The Breusch-Pagan test is used to detect:
Lack of normality in residuals
Influential observations
Heteroscedasticity (non-constant error variance)
Multicollinearity among predictors
